Expectation1: Maintain regular communication with family members
Situation1: A family holiday is approaching, which is a traditional time for everyone to reconnect.
Situation2: They see a group of teenagers ignoring the no-diving signs near the pool edge.
Story: The pool was crowded, laughter echoing off the water as the holiday weekend approached. My phone buzzed in my pocket—another message from my daughter, reminding me about the family dinner tonight. “Don’t forget, Dad. Everyone’s counting on you to be there.” I smiled, picturing my grandkids, but my attention snapped back to the pool. A group of teenagers clustered near the deep end, daring each other to dive despite the bold red “NO DIVING” signs. My supervisor’s words echoed in my mind: “Zero tolerance. Safety first, always.” I felt the weight of the whistle around my neck, the responsibility to keep everyone safe. But my heart tugged in another direction—my family expected me to be present, to share stories and laughter, to be the grandfather they could rely on. I stood at the pool’s edge, torn between blowing the whistle and enforcing the rules, or slipping away to answer my family’s call, both roles demanding all of me at once.
